profileAlternative.name: Adam McCullough
profileAlternative.headline: Software Engineer
profileAlternative.summary: With eight years of professional experience and 15 years of active experience, I draw from embedded, QA, Operations, DBA, and web back-end perspectives to bring excellence to the engineering work I do.

aboutAlternative.text: With eight years of professional experience and 15 years of active experience, I draw from embedded, QA, Operations, DBA, and web back-end perspectives to bring excellence to the engineering work I do.

positions.title: Software Engineer
positions.description: Fix, improve, and update a diverse codebase, primarily in PHP and Haskell, but also including Twig template files, JS, and CSS. Work with other teams to extend the site to meet new requirements, up to and including refactoring and re-writing major features. Work with the Ops team to identify and resolve causes of service quality impact. Identify causes of potential trouble, and possible solutions.

positions.title: Software Intern
positions.description: Developed hard drive test software. Designed and developed a test suite for the backplanes used to test said drives. Refactored a drive erase program , and expanded functionality for a customer. Assisted in running and developing a flash characterization test/burn-in procedure using both hardware, embedded firmware, and software written in the .NET framework.

positions.title: Software Intern
positions.description: Same as before. SMART Modular acquired Adtron. My employment did not stop. Currently working on software and hardware testing/verification.

positions.title: Library Page
positions.description: Shelved returns, customer service, and helped in library maintenance. (shifts, checking that the shelves were consistent with LC, etc)

educations.title: Arizona State University
educations.fieldofstudy: Programming, Hardware Design, French, CAD, Psychology, Philosophy, Mathematics

given.text:
Adam reported to me as a linux sysadmin at IMVU. I was very happy to work with Adam, and I'd be happy if I get the chance to work with him again in the future. Adam has a strong commitment towards improving engineering practices and doing things right. Adam worked to develop his programming skills and I was sad to lose him on my team when he moved to a software engineering team. Adam has solid linux fundamentals, and a very good appreciation for what's necessary in building stable, reliable production services.
…
See more

Adam picked up things very quickly. For example, shortly after arriving, he was given an application written in C by a previous employee and quickly cleaned it up and greatly added to its functionality.

Adam is an intelligent, tenacious, and detail-oriented person. He is always willing to go the extra mile to ensure deadlines are met and will assist wherever required. In addition, he actively reviews current processes and identifies ways to improve or automate them. I thoroughly enjoyed working with Adam and highly recommend him.

Adam is a highly adaptable engineer. He can take on new projects, new languages or new tools, learn them and be productive in a short amount of time. His open communication style serves well for understanding team members.

received.text:
I worked with Stephen for almost two years at IMVU. I was one of his direct reports, and I worked with him regularly in his role as team Tech Lead.

I thoroughly enjoyed working with and learning from Stephen. He's an extraordinarily capable engineer, with a deep understanding of LAMP administration, Site Reliability Engineering, and scaling up a production cluster. In addition, he's a very capable tech lead, for two reasons:

First, he has what I can only call excellent taste in technology choices, and lead several projects that made life on the Operations team much better. Second, he's a gifted and experienced teacher and mentor. He's mentored several ops engineers on the team, including myself. I want to stress this, because finding effective mentors and teachers in this industry is exceptionally rare. Every question I asked him was answered charitably, with either a clear, specific, in-depth explanation, or a quick "That's a great question! I don't know. Give me a minute."

I feel lucky to have worked with him. I learned much and would welcome the opportunity to work with him again.

When I first walked into her Tango I class, I was a very out-of-place left-brained engineer who had never taken a rhythmic step in his life. As I stumbled (and fumbled, and tripped) may way through that first month, the thing that stands out the most is how Daniela -- an exceptionally competent, elegant, and proficient dancer -- was able to not just meet me half-way, but well past that to where I stood (or landed) at the time.

Now, almost two years later, I can't recommend her guidance, support, and teaching talent enough. I've gone from a graceless klutz to someone who gets compliments from long-time tango dancers on a regular basis.

All you need is a willingness to learn. Daniela's experience, wisdom, and knowledge will provide the raw material to learn from.

A parting warning: Her passion, enthusiasm, and love of the dance is contagious.
